theories.name: Communities of Practice (Wenger)
theories.rationale: The current model captures movement from periphery to core but lacks key CoP concepts like legitimate peripheral participation, boundary processes, and shared practice development. Adding these elements will better represent how newcomers become integrated into the community through meaningful participation and how the community's identity and practice evolve over time.

variables.name: Legitimate Peripheral Participation Opportunities
variables.description: Availability of meaningful but low-risk tasks that allow newcomers to participate and learn

variables.name: Community Boundary Strength
variables.description: Degree to which the community maintains distinct identity and practices

variables.name: Shared Practice Development Rate
variables.description: Rate at which community practices, norms, and tools evolve through collective activity

theories.name: Nonaka's SECI Model
theories.rationale: The current model has implicit and explicit knowledge transfer but doesn't capture the full knowledge spiral of socialization, externalization, combination, and internalization. Adding these processes will better represent how tacit knowledge becomes explicit and gets re-integrated, creating a dynamic knowledge creation cycle essential for organizational learning.

variables.name: Tacit Knowledge Base
variables.description: Accumulated experiential knowledge held by community members

variables.name: Knowledge Externalization Rate
variables.description: Rate at which tacit knowledge is converted to explicit forms through articulation

variables.name: Knowledge Combination Rate
variables.description: Rate at which explicit knowledge elements are combined and systematized

variables.name: Knowledge Internalization Rate
variables.description: Rate at which explicit knowledge is absorbed and becomes tacit understanding
